awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  User-Friendly Spirometer and Mobile App for Self-Management and Home Monitoring of Asthma Patients
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase II project is the development of a user-friendly asthma management solution. The asthma management tool consists of a portable medical device and mobile app combination that measures lung function with the consistency and accuracy of a trained lab technician, displaying current asthma status, and providing health insights to act upon. During the 2-year duration of this proposal, the applicant will further develop a machine-learning algorithm that obtains the same level of consistency and accuracy as if a trained lab technician were coaching and correcting the asthmatic patient on proper usage. Steps will be taken to establish the efficacy of such technology through verification of classification by pulmonologists. In order to engage users to continue using the product over several months, gamification elements will be implemented into the mobile app. By expanding on the machine-model through a longitudinal study, earlier detection of asthma exacerbations may be identified. Early detection leads to improved self-management as measured by the reduction of severe asthma attacks, the use of systemic corticosteroids, hospitalizations, emergency department or urgent care visits related to asthma.

The proposed project aims to develop an asthma management tool that provides parents a simple way to reliably monitor their child's lung health, eliminating the guesswork associated with relying on symptoms alone. The rate of asthma continues to rise, with an increasing amount of healthcare utilization among asthmatic individuals. Effective technologies for proper management remain trapped within the hospital due to high costs and requirement of a skilled lab technician for proper measurement collection. This proposal aims to develop an algorithm alongside UCSF pediatric pulmonologists to gain consistent and accurate spirometry measurements, so that only proper measurements are acted upon. Our machine-learning algorithm will determine the cause of failure and prompt the user on corrective action to achieve a good quality measurement on a subsequent effort. By the end of this proposal period, the applicant will have a mobile app algorithm that is able to achieve the consistency of a trained lab technician, provide effective corrective feedback, engage users over the span of months for consistent lung monitoring, and potentially predict the onset of an asthma attack.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The prevalence of asthma continues to rise and so is the number of asthma attacks. However, effective technologies for proper management largely remain confined to the in-hospital or in-clinic setting due to prohibitive equipment costs, requirement of a respiratory therapist to ensure proper testing, and pulmonologist interpretation of results. Early detection of lung health decline enables preventative action to reduce severe asthma attacks, emergency department or urgent care visits, and hospitalizations related to asthma.

This NSF STTR Phase II project extended developments from the NSF STTR Phase I project to commercialize an AI-enabled respiratory management platform that gains consistent and accurate spirometry measurements, in addition to collecting medication, symptoms and geolocation data. We increased the accuracy of the machine learning classification algorithm, provided real-time corrective feedback to influence proper technique, and improved the mobile application to engage users over the course of months to years for consistent remote monitoring. Significant improvements in accuracy and feedback were achieved through implementing artificial neural networks (ANN). As part of the project, the team worked closely with asthmatic users and a professional game developer to properly utilize gamification techniques that encourage daily lung function and health data collection. Regular usage enables health insights to be derived in a shorter time period.  

The project faced a few minor challenges during the user enrollment process, as it was impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic which ceased all in-person clinical and research activities at University of California San Francisco (UCSF). Consequently, users were recruited through social media, telehealth and private medical practices (including those who were prescribed by their clinicians). As providers could no longer assess patients in-person during the pandemic, a clinician dashboard was built to be used for remotely monitoring patients, detecting declining lung health, helping improve speed and determining impact of early medical intervention. Features were deployed to learn how providers intervene based on declining health triggers to train algorithms based on real-world data.

Overall, this technology enables a data-driven approach for patients and healthcare providers to assess lung health in between office visits and for providers to make improvements to the treatment plan to regain asthma control faster. 

 


Last Modified: 06/04/2024
Modified by: Charvi Shetty
